awd_titl_txt: CI-SUSTAIN: Sustainable Tools for Analysis and Research on Darknet Unsolicited Traffic (STARDUST).
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet is a vast enterprise carrying information to people and devices all over the world.  The University of California San Diego Network Telescope (UCSD-NT) is a unique monitoring system which, for over a decade, has enabled global visibility into Internet behavior that few other data sources can offer.  It has provided relevant data used in a broad set of sub-disciplines in Computer & Information Science & Engineering (CISE) and beyond, from network and systems security and stability, to machine learning and big data processing techniques, and, most recently, for studies of cyberwarfare.  The STARDUST project will help sustain operation and extend the applicability of the UCSD-NT infrastructure.  The stabilized and enhanced infrastructure capabilities will serve a diverse range of academic researchers, the vast majority of whom have no access to any other source of global Internet traffic data.  In addition, the proposed enhancements will support invaluable hands-on experience in operationally relevant network security and traffic analysis research for a wide audience of computer science students.

STARDUST aims at maintaining continued operation of the UCSD-NT infrastructure while maximizing its utility to researchers from various disciplines.  The scope of work includes upgrading and modernizing the current infrastructure to handle the predicted growth in traffic, leveraging virtualization and NSF-funded High-Performance Computing (HPC) platforms at the San Diego Supercomputer Center for computational data analysis, and introducing meta-data semantics to simplify many tasks researchers typically want to do with UCSD-NT data.  The proposed modifications will leave researchers more time (and available HPC resources) to focus on their specific scientific questions.  Moreover, the project will forge an interdisciplinary collaboration between researchers from the field of computer networks and HPC scientists and engineers to experiment with novel approaches for research on live traffic analysis.  Project results will contribute to advancing knowledge in diverse CISE disciplines, e.g., facilitating the development of efficient strategies for early detection and mitigation of cyber attacks, supporting macroscopic Internet performance and reliability assessments, and opening a new domain for the application of live streaming big data analysis techniques.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The UCSD Network Telescope (UCSD-NT) is a complex research infrastructure hosted at University of California San Diego, capturing unsolicited traffic continuously originating from the whole Internet and sent to a large segment of unassigned IPv4 address space. Such traffic, a sort of Internet pollution traffic, is also known as Internet Background Radiation (IBR).

For almost two decades, the UCSD-NT has enabled global visibility into macroscopic Internet phenomena that few other data sources can provide. The relevance of this community research infrastructure for the study of the Internet is reflected by a vast scientific literature in a broad set of sub-disciplines in CISE and beyond, from network and systems security and stability, to machine learning and big data processing techniques, and most recently to studies of cyberwarfare and political repression of communication.

Despite its relevance, before the start of this project, the state of this infrastructure was lagging behind the increasing demands, in terms of storage, computing resources, and system administration. These issues hindered the ability of the scientific community to continue benefitting from such a precious resource (and, before the start of this project, had already required compromises that limited its utility to the community). This project dramatically modernized the UCSD-NT software and hardware infrastructure and enabled much more sustainable long-term operations, while also increasing its accessibility and utility to the research community through (i) data enrichment, (ii) additional data formats, (iii) a large set of tools, and (iv) extensive documentation. At the core of our work there are the design and deployment of a novel modular software-hardware architecture that can scale with future increases in data rates, paired with capabilities leveraging virtualization and cloud infrastructure to serve researchers' computing needs.

Intellectual Merit. The project results contributed to advancing knowledge in CISE disciplines, including revealing new trends in malicious scanning campaigns and providing a new domain for the application of live streaming big data analysis, and in situ machine learning techniques. This project also resulted in an interdisciplinary collaboration between researchers from the field of computer networks and high-performance computing scientists and engineers to experiment with novel approaches leveraging computing infrastructure for research on traffic analysis.  By upgrading the infrastructure to sustain predicted growth in use for several years, we are stabilizing and enhancing our ability to serve a diverse range of academic researchers, the vast majority of whom have no access to any other source of global Internet traffic data.

Broader impacts. We disseminated project results via: two dedicated community workshops that we organized and hosted (with large participation from both industry and academia), publishing and presenting papers at conferences, and a new dedicated web site dedicated to both admitted and prospective users.  We also continued our engagement with faculty and graduate students in the use of our tools and data. We also fostered community use of UCSD-NT data through the DHS Information Marketplace for Policy and Analysis of Cyber-risk and Trust (IMPACT) program, which allowed us to leverage cross-agency support for data sharing activities. Finally, our improvements to the STARDUST infrastructure also contributed to provide key realtime data to the IODA project (Internet Outage Detection and Analysis --- https://ioda.live). Funded by the NSF, the DHS S&T, and the Department of State, the IODA project has significant impact in the fields of human rights (United Nations, Amnesty International), public safety (FCC), and critical infrastructure reliability (DHS), while through its public dashboards it contributes to the broader dissemination of empirical evidence to the general public and media.

Project website: https://stardust.caida.org


Last Modified: 03/13/2022
Modified by: Alberto Dainotti
